customer_addr:

Belle Center, OH 43310

citations.narrative:
A method of identification for puppies less than 16 weeks of age is not currently being used. The licensee states one litter
of 4 puppies has a cage card but it is at his home (30 minutes away). The other litter has 6 puppies that are only 1-2
weeks old and the licensee states he has not made a cage card for them yet. Proper identification of dogs is important for
disease trace back, or in cases of theft or loss. Class "A" dealers shall identify all live dogs on the premises. Correct by
ensuring proper identification is used, documented, and maintained for all dogs at the facility. Correct by: August 30,
2023.

Of the 25 adult dogs at the facility, 9 of them were missing from the APHIS form 7005 Record of Acquisition and Dogs on
Hand (36%). It is important to maintain an updated Record of Acquisition and Dogs on Hand for ease of inspection,
tracking movements of animals, and for recovery in instances of loss or theft. Correct by ensuring the APHIS form 7005 is
regularly maintained with up-to-date information of the dogs at the facility. Correct by: August 30, 2023.

A fawn Male Pug, “Grizz”, has significant buildup of hard, brown organic debris on the teeth of the upper jaw. On the right
side a premolar (tooth directly behind the canine tooth) has root exposure and appears loose. The right third incisor (tooth
directly in front of the canine tooth) has a similar appearance with a significant accumulation of hard, brown organic
debris, root exposure, and may be loose. The dog is not thin and did not show pain on oral inspection. There is also a
buildup of waxy, dark brown material in both ears of this dog. The ears are not red and the ears do not appear to make
the dog uncomfortable.
Buildup of hard, brown debris on the teeth, exposure of the tooth roots, and loose teeth can be signs of dental disease.
Dental disease can be a source of pain and infection for dogs, possibly leading to problems eating, weight loss, or tooth
loss. Excessive debris in the ears can be a sign of an ear problem. While there are several causes of ear problems in
dogs, they can all lead to discomfort, excessive head shaking, stress, and decreased hearing.
The licensee must ensure that preventative care and treatments are being regularly performed to ensure healthy skin,
ears, eyes, and teeth, in accordance with the established Program of Vet Care. Correct by contacting the Attending
Veterinarian for an evaluation of this dog. Correct by: August 18, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.50(b)(3) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
A method of identification for puppies less than 16 weeks of age is not currently being used. The licensee states one litter 
of 4 puppies has a cage card but it is at his home (30 minutes away). The other litter has 6 puppies that are only 1-2 
weeks old and the licensee states he has not made a cage card for them yet. Proper identification of dogs is important for 
disease trace back, or in cases of theft or loss. Class "A" dealers shall identify all live dogs on the premises. Correct by 
ensuring proper identification is used, documented, and maintained for all dogs at the facility. Correct by: August 30, 
2023. 
2.75(a)(2) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Of the 25 adult dogs at the facility, 9 of them were missing from the APHIS form 7005 Record of Acquisition and Dogs on 
Hand (36%). It is important to maintain an updated Record of Acquisition and Dogs on Hand for ease of inspection, 
tracking movements of animals, and for recovery in instances of loss or theft. Correct by ensuring the APHIS form 7005 is 
regularly maintained with up-to-date information of the dogs at the facility. Correct by: August 30, 2023. 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
A fawn Male Pug, “Grizz”, has significant buildup of hard, brown organic debris on the teeth of the upper jaw. On the right 
side a premolar (tooth directly behind the canine tooth) has root exposure and appears loose. The right third incisor (tooth 
directly in front of the canine tooth) has a similar appearance with a significant accumulation of hard, brown organic 
debris, root exposure, and may be loose. The dog is not thin and did not show pain on oral inspection. There is also a 
buildup of waxy, dark brown material in both ears of this dog. The ears are not red and the ears do not appear to make 
the dog uncomfortable.  
 
Buildup of hard, brown debris on the teeth, exposure of the tooth roots, and loose teeth can be signs of dental disease. 
Dental disease can be a source of pain and infection for dogs, possibly leading to problems eating, weight loss, or tooth 
loss. Excessive debris in the ears can be a sign of an ear problem. While there are several causes of ear problems in 
dogs, they can all lead to discomfort, excessive head shaking, stress, and decreased hearing.

The licensee must ensure that preventative care and treatments are being regularly performed to ensure healthy skin, 
ears, eyes, and teeth, in accordance with the established Program of Vet Care. Correct by contacting the Attending 
Veterinarian for an evaluation of this dog. Correct by: August 18, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
